Answer:
<div class="post-text" itemprop="text">
<p>Your pattern contains <code>(?(?=ls)yes|no)</code> which is literally looking ahead for the characters <code>ls</code>. I've changed your pattern to utilize the <code>DEFINE</code> construct for subpattern reusability. As far as I'm aware, PCRE does not have a method to check whether or not a group was defined <em>after</em> the conditional. This can be accomplished in <a href="/questions/tagged/.net" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged '.net'" rel="tag">.net</a> with the use of balancing groups, but PCRE doesn't employ those methods. PCRE does have the <code>(?(name)yes|no)</code> or <code>(?(1)yes|no)</code> conditional, but it doesn't work for forward references (comparative to testing whether or not a variable exists before it's even declared).</p>

<p><a href="https://regex101.com/r/u1JJOg/5" rel="nofollow noreferrer">See regex in use here</a></p>

<pre><code>(?(DEFINE)
  (?# var )
  (?&lt;var&gt;[a-zA-Z_\x7f-\xff][\w\x7f-\xff]*)
  (?# val )
  (?&lt;val&gt;(?&amp;call)|(?&amp;str)|(?&amp;num)|(?&amp;bool))
  (?&lt;call&gt;\$\{CALL\s+[a-zA-Z_\x7f-\xff][\w\x7f-\xff]*\s*\})
  (?&lt;str&gt;"[^"]*"|'[^']*')
  (?&lt;num&gt;\d+)
  (?&lt;bool&gt;(?i)(?:false|true)(?-i))
)
((?(?=yes\${VAR\s+(?&amp;var)\s*\=\s*(?&amp;val)\s*\}\s)yes|no))
\${(?P&lt;type&gt;VAR)\s+((?&amp;var))\s*\=\s*((?&amp;val))\s*\}(\S)?
</code></pre>

<p>Without duplicating the subpattern in the positive lookahead, you can use the following (<a href="https://regex101.com/r/u1JJOg/7" rel="nofollow noreferrer">as seen in use here</a>). The token <code>(?8)</code> recurses the 8th capture group:</p>

<pre><code>(?(DEFINE)
  (?# var )
  (?&lt;var&gt;[a-zA-Z_\x7f-\xff][\w\x7f-\xff]*)
  (?# val )
  (?&lt;val&gt;(?&amp;call)|(?&amp;str)|(?&amp;num)|(?&amp;bool))
  (?&lt;call&gt;\$\{CALL\s+[a-zA-Z_\x7f-\xff][\w\x7f-\xff]*\s*\})
  (?&lt;str&gt;"[^"]*"|'[^']*')
  (?&lt;num&gt;\d+)
  (?&lt;bool&gt;(?i)(?:false|true)(?-i))
)
((?(?=no(?8)\S)no|yes))
(\${(?P&lt;type&gt;VAR)\s+((?&amp;var))\s*\=\s*((?&amp;val))\s*\})(\S)?
</code></pre>
    </div>
